Purpose
The purpose of the RMP is to reduce and minimize the occurrence and the consequences of releases of anhydrous ammonia from the refrigeration process. This section summarizes the programs, policies, and procedures in place to reduce the risk of a hazardous materials release.
SEMCO will utilize current and appropriate engineering practices to inspect refrigeration equipment prior to start up and during operations. These procedures identify potential sources of release and subsequent equipment corrections required to prevent these releases. Onsite personnel and certified refrigeration contractors regularly inspect the equipment, as required.
Description of Source and Substance Handled
The SEMCO facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia in their produce and cold storage operations. The refrigeration plant is comprised of one stationary process that provides refrigeration for cold rooms, portable vacuum cooling, pressure cooling and ice manufacturing. Produce is brought to the facility where it is pre-cooled and stored for processing and shipment. 
All refrigeration equipment is tied together in a single common system. This equipment consists of portable and permanently installed equipment. The refrigeration system configuration includes two compressor skids, one portable high-side refrigeration trailer, a high pressure/storage receiver, a low pressure receiver pumping unit, an ice maker pumping unit, a suction accumulator, one full  vacuum tube system consisting of two A? car units joined together, cold room evaporators, pressure cooling evaporators, ice makers, evaporative  condenser, and related safety equipment which includes a refrigerant discharge and diffusion tank system. 
The system is operated in the full configuration during the growing season from April through November. Most portable units are relocated to other facilities during the off season. Minimal cooling operations occur during the off season.
Ammonia is the only listed material used at this facilit

y. The plant operates with a total charge of approximately 22,680 lbs. of ammonia distributed throughout the facility. 
The ammonia charge is contained primarily in the high pressure receivers and the low pressure pump receivers. The remainder of the refrigerant is contained within the piping and the refrigeration coils.  
 Ammonia Refrigeration
The refrigeration system is a single-stage vapor compression cycle. In general, the process chemistry is as follows:
1.    Low pressure vapor is compressed to high pressure gas by refrigeration compressors.
2.    High pressure vapor is condensed to high pressure liquid by the evaporative condenser.  Condensation occurs because of heat rejection to ambient resulting from the evaporation of water sprayed on the condenser coil.
3.    High pressure liquid gravity feeds from the condenser to the high pressure receiver where it is stored until needed.
4.    High pressure ammonia is fed from the high pressure receiver to the low pressure vessels.  This is made possible by the pressure differential between the two types of vessels.  Pressure is dropped when the liquid passes though an expansion device located between the high and low pressure vessels.
5.    The evaporators are recirculation types where low pressure liquid is pumped from low pressure receiver. The evaporators are room coils for maintaining cold room or freezer storage temperatures.
6.    Evaporation of the low pressure liquid occurs due to warmer air coming in contact with the evaporators. The evaporation produces the cooling effect.  
A mixture of liquid and vapor is returned to the low pressure vessel. Low pressure vapor is drawn off by the compressors and the liquid is circulated back through the room coils. The ammonia refrigeration system consists of compressors, evaporative refrigerant condenser, pressure vessels for storage of refrigerant and system operations for various cooling applications, and interconnecting piping and electronic controls. A complete list of the various co

mponents of the ammonia refrigeration system is located in SEMCO's CAL-ARP Binder.
Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is a gas in its natural state and is extremely irritating to mucous membranes and lung tissue. The gas is pungent and may cause suffocation, as shortness of breath and labored breathing can develop if inhaled. Prolonged inhalation of high concentrations may cause bronchitis and/ or pneumonia, with some residual reduction in pulmonary functions. Repeated or prolonged contact of high concentrations of ammonia to the skin can cause frostbite, redness, pain, and serious skin burn. 
Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy
SEMCO Cooling has implemented the Risk Management Plan (RMP) at the Salinas, California facility in order to comply with the regulations, and to fulfill this facility's responsibility to protecting its employees, equipment, property, the surrounding community, and the environment from accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.
The purpose of the RMP is to reduce and minimize the occurrence and the consequences of releases of anhydrous ammonia from the refrigeration process. The following summarizes the programs, policies, and procedures in place to reduce the risk of a hazardous materials release.
Accidental Release Prevention Program
SEMCO maintains an accidental release prevention program to eliminate or minimize releases. The program includes equipment monitoring, regular inspections and maintenance, and log keeping of (1) operating conditions, (2) scheduled maintenance, (3) emergency response, and (4) operator training. 
The program consists of pre-start up inspection, emergency response, and regular training. The existing RMP for the facility was updated from the original RMPP in 2002. A Hazards Analysis (PHA or HAZOP) was performed in 2008, and re-validated for this RMP. Equipment corrections and updates were made for those items determined to have the highest potential for offsite releases in this 2009 RMP update.
Safety and equipmen

t operational training is conducted on a yearly basis and includes equipment operational procedures, emergency response procedures, review of Business Response Procedures, and evacuation procedures. Additional items requiring further review, correction, and/or updating will be identified.
Refrigeration equipment will be reviewed and the RMP will be updated when changes to equipment occur or when new equipment is brought on-site. 
The operations at this facility are seasonal with operations occurring primarily between the months of April through November during the produce growing season. The equipment is inspected during the off-season and any repairs or change outs are made at this time. This off-season time is used to prepare the equipment for non-stop operation during the season.
Currently, ammonia system operating controls are fairly state of the art. The compressors are individually controlled with factory solid state micro processor controls or manually set Penn-style electromechanical switches. These control capacity by operating the compressor unloading based on suction pressure. The control settings for each machine indicate the control levels for suction pressure, discharge pressure, and oil pressure. Shut-down limits exist for low suction pressure, high discharge pressure and temperature, low discharge pressure, and high oil temperature. There is also a differential pressure control for oil pressure failure. If the differential between oil pressure and compressor suction pressure becomes too large, the compressor will stop, preventing damage to the machine. The display provided on the compressor control panel can be used to confirm these set point levels and actual pressures. If a compressor fails it is locked out and the system control starts another machine. The Control System Microprocessor also protects against abnormal conditions. 
Liquid ammonia reaching the refrigeration compressors could cause equipment failure. However, the system utilizes a suct

ion accumulator to intercept liquid returning in the suction line. This accumulator captures any liquid carry over from the evaporators and chiller system thus protecting the compressor from liquid slugging. The suction accumulator has a high level cut out which provides additional protection and provides shutdown of compressors and notification in the event of a high level occurrence.
Safety relief valves are factory set to relieve the system if pressure reaches above 250 psig on the low side or 250 psig on the high side. There are dual relief valves on the high and low pressure receiver and on the compressor oil separator. A three-way valve allows one of the valves to be serviced while the other continues to provide protection. The sizing, piping, and condition of the relief valves were checked during the field survey. Relief valves are installed on all system components. The pressure relief valve discharges are collected into a common header and discharged to water filled diffuser tank. Relief valves should be re-certified or replaced once every five years.
Ammonia releases will be sensed by on-site personnel. Notification to other employees in the event of a release will be by intercom or by radio system.
Initial emergency response is provided by onsite personnel.  Onsite personnel will make a preliminary assessment in the event of a release and will provide first response.  First response may include emergency equipment shutdown, system isolation, or controlled operation such as pump down to prevent or reduce an off-site release. No emergency operations will be performed that are beyond the capabilities of the operators or other onsite personnel. Emergency response for a major release event will be provided by local fire and police departments with mutual aide response. The refrigeration contractor would also be on-call to provide emergency response.

No emergency operations will be performed that are beyond the capabilities of the operators or other onsite per

sonnel. Emergency response training will be conducted yearly for current employees and as required for new employees. Records will be kept of all training performed at the site for a minimum of five (5) years. Emergency contact information is included in Section V.
Safety
The ammonia refrigeration operation system has specific safety measures in place to prevent accidental release. Operators and mechanics are trained for safe operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system. They are also trained in emergency response procedures in the event of an ammonia release. An alarm and detection system monitors the process areas for unsafe ammonia concentration levels.  Equipment is monitored for operating conditions outside of safety set points. All relief valves are tied into an ammonia diffusion tank, allowing system pressures to be relieved without releasing to ambient.
Training
Safety and equipment operational training will be conducted on a yearly basis and will include equipment operational procedures, emergency response procedures, review of general Risk Management Plan procedures, review of the Emergency Response Plan, and evacuation procedures.
Updates
As required in Section VI, Updates, refrigeration equipment will be inspected and reviewed periodically and as new equipment becomes operational onsite. This RMP, which includes accident prevention procedures for the ammonia refrigeration system, is maintained onsite. 
Five-Year Accident History
No reportable releases or accidents relating to the release of ammonia have occurred at the facility in the last five years. Releases of ammonia, should they occur, will be responded to in accordance with company policy and the procedures outlined in this RMP.
Emergency Response Program
SEMCO Company has implemented the State and County mandated emergency response plan (Business Response Plan.) This plan outlines procedures for emergency ammonia release response, as well as general response. Section V outlines emergency

response procedures at this facility. 
In event of a release, certain personnel are designated to determine the potential hazard and coordinate response procedures. 
The emergency coordinator is responsible for contacting emergency response agencies, schools, daycare centers, and acute care facilities that may be affected by an offsite release. The coordinator will also be responsible for evacuation of employees if necessary and for coordination with community emergency responders if offsite evacuations are required.
The emergency response program consists of the following elements:
A?    Contact phone numbers for emergency coordinator and emergency contacts
A?    Notification procedures
A?    Hazardous material incident response to ammonia releases and other incidents
A?    Coordinator and personnel responsibilities
A?    Releases to be reported
A?    Evacuation plans
A?    Emergency response checklist
A?    Emergency shutdown procedures
A?    Emergency response training
Planned Safety Improvements
Safety improvements have been identified during the preparation of this program. These improvements have been documented and a schedule developed for their implementation. Some of these improvements include change out of pressure relief valves five years or older, and development of operational procedures. Additional safety improvements may be identified during the upcoming PHA revalidation.
